<line: 22> )  
<line: 23> Police Officer of Orland Park, a municipal corp.,  
<line: 24> )  Magistrate Judge Cox  
<line: 25> SILVER LAKE COUNTRY CLUB, INC. and  
<line: 26> )  
<line: 27> VILLAGE OF ORLAND PARK, a municipal corp. )  
<line: 28> )
<line: 29> Defendants  
<line: 30> )  

[TITLE]
<line: 32> DEFENDANT VILLAGE OF ORLAND PARK'S, ANSWER TO PLAINTIFFS' 
<line: 33> AMENDED COMPLAINT AT LAW

[TEXT]
<line: 35> NOW COMES the defendant, VILLAGE OF ORLAND PARK, by and through its 
<line: 36> attorneys, LITCHFIELD CAVO LLP and for its answer to plaintiffs’ Amended Complaint at 
<line: 37> Law, states as follow: 

[TITLE]
<line: 39> COMMON FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS

[TEXT]
<line: 41> 1. 
<line: 42> At all times relevant herein, the Plaintiffs, ANDREW TERRELL and GEORGE 
<line: 43> TERRELL were residents of the County of Cook and State of Illinois. 

[TEXT]
<line: 45> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph one. 

[TEXT]
<line: 47> 2. 
<line: 48> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI was a resident of 
<line: 49> County of Cook and State of Illinois. 

[TEXT]
<line: 51> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph two. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 53> -1- 

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 2 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 3. 
<line: 5> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was employed by 
<line: 6> the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, as a security guard. 

[TEXT]
<line: 8> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph three. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> 4. 
<line: 11> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was employed by 
<line: 12> the Defendant, Orland Park, as a police officer. 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph four. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> 5. 
<line: 17> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, was a duly licensed 
<line: 18> corporation, incorporated in the State of Illinois and doing business as Silver Lake Country Club 
<line: 19> and located at 14700 South 82nd Avenue in the City of Orland Park, County of Cook, and State 
<line: 20> of Illinois. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph five. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> 6. 
<line: 25> On or about March 18, 2006, the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, and his 
<line: 26> fiancée were married at Queen of Martyrs Church in Evergreen Park. Immediately after the 
<line: 27> wedding ceremony, the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, his fiancée, and various other members 
<line: 28> of the wedding guests, including the Plaintiff GEORGE TERRELL, attended a wedding 
<line: 29> reception at Silver Lake Country Club. 

[TEXT]
<line: 31> ANSWER: Defendant neither admits nor denies the allegations contained in paragraph six, but 
<line: 32> demands strict proof thereto. 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> 7. 
<line: 35> The Defendant, PETER DIANGI, grabbed the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, 
<line: 36> by the arm. 

[TEXT]
<line: 38> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph seven. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 40> -2- 

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 3 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 8. 
<line: 5> Prior to grabbing the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, the Defendant, PETER 
<line: 6> DIANGI, did not identify himself as a security guard or other employee of Silver Lake, nor did 
<line: 7> he identify himself as a police officer. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph eight. 

[TEXT]
<line: 11> 9. 
<line: 12> Subsequent to grabbing the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, the Defendant, 
<line: 13> PETER DIANGI, grabbed ANDREW Terrell by the neck. A melee ensued as wedding guests 
<line: 14> attempted to defend the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph nine. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> 10. 
<line: 19> At all times, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was dressed in "plain clothes", and 
<line: 20> was not wearing a police uniform. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph ten. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> 11. 
<line: 25> As a result of the aforestated melee, the Plaintiffs, ANDREW TERRELL and 
<line: 26> GEORGE TERRELL, were arrested and charged with battery. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph eleven. 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> 12. 
<line: 31> The arrests of the Plaintiffs were made under false pretenses, given that the 
<line: 32> Defendant, PETER DIANGI, justigated the events leading to the aforesaid arrests.  

[TEXT]
<line: 34> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph twelve. 

[TEXT]
<line: 36> 13. 
<line: 37> The Defendant, PETER DIANGI, engaged in conduct against the plaintiffs, 
<line: 38> which conduct included striking the plaintiffs, grabbing the plaintiffs and spraying with pepper 
<line: 39> spray. 

[TEXT]
<line: 41>  ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph thirteen. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 43> -3- 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 4 of 39

[TITLE]
<line: 4> COUNT I-BATTERY

[TITLE]
<line: 6> (Andrew Terrell v. Peter Diangi)

[TEXT]
<line: 8> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 9> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count I, as though 
<line: 10> fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference. 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count I are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 13> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> 14. 
<line: 16> The conduct and force used by PETER DIANGI toward the Plaintiff, ANDREW 
<line: 17> TERRELL, was intentional, malicious, excessive and in reckless disregard of the Plaintiffs' 
<line: 18> constitutional rights. Moreover, the use of force used against the Plaintiff was excessive.  

[TEXT]
<line: 20> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count I are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 21> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> 15. 
<line: 24> As a result of the aforementioned conduct of the Defendants, the Plaintiff 
<line: 25> suffered serious physical injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, 
<line: 26> including physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count I are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 29> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 31> 16. 
<line: 32> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 33> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 35> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count I are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 36> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 38> -4- 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 5 of 39

[TITLE]
<line: 4> COUNT II-ASSAULT

[TITLE]
<line: 6> (Andrew Terrell v. Peter Diangi)

[TEXT]
<line: 8> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 9> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count II, as though 
<line: 10> fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference.  

[TEXT]
<line: 12> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count II are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 13> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> 14. The Defendants' conduct placed Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL in apprehension of 
<line: 16> immediate and imminent harm to his well being and safety, and he suffered great shame and 
<line: 17> humiliation and injury to his dignity and feelings, upsetting his mentally, emotionally and 
<line: 18> psychologically. 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count II are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 21> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TITLE]
<line: 23> COUNT III – NEGLIGENCE

[TITLE]
<line: 25> (Andrew Terrell v. Peter Diangi)

[TEXT]
<line: 27> 1. 
<line: 28> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was employed by 
<line: 29> the Defendant,  SILVER LAKE, as a security guard.  

[TEXT]
<line: 31> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count III are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 32> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> 2. 
<line: 35>  At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, was a duly licensed 
<line: 36> corporation, incorporated in the State of Illinois and doing business as Silver Lake Country Club 

[ABANDON]
<line: 38> -5- 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 6 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> and located at 14700 South 82nd Avenue in the City of Orland Park, County of Cook, and State 
<line: 5> of Illinois. 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count III are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 8> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> 3. 
<line: 11> On or about March 18, 2006, the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, and his 
<line: 12> fiancée were married at Queen of Martyrs Church in Evergreen Park. Immediately after the 
<line: 13> wedding ceremony, the plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, his fiancée, and various other members 
<line: 14> of the wedding guests, including the Plaintiff GEORGE TERRELL, attended a wedding 
<line: 15> reception at Silver Lake Country Club. 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count III are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 18> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> 4. 
<line: 21> During the course of the reception, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was engaged 
<line: 22> in his ordinary duties as a security guard and was working in his capacity as employee or agent 
<line: 23> of the Defendant, SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 25> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count III are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 26> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> 5. 
<line: 29> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant PETER DIANGI owed a duty of 
<line: 30> ordinary care to the Plaintiff while performing his tasks as a security officer. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count III are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 33> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 35> 6. 
<line: 36> On March 18, 2006, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, breached his aforesaid duty 
<line: 37> by engaging in one or more of the following negligent acts or omissions: 

[ABANDON]
<line: 39> -6- 

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 7 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> a. 
<line: 5> Negligently failed to identify himself as a security guard or employee of Silver 
<line: 6> Lake; 
<line: 7> b. 
<line: 8> Negligently pushed the Plaintiff; 
<line: 9> c. 
<line: 10> Negligently sprayed the Plaintiff with pepper spray; 
<line: 11> d. 
<line: 12> Negligently attempted to physically restrain the plaintiff; and/or 
<line: 13> e. 
<line: 14> Was otherwise negligent. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count III are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 17> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 19> 7. As a result of the aforementioned conduct of the Defendants, the Plaintiff suffered 
<line: 20> serious physical injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including 
<line: 21> physical and emotional pain in and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count III are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 24> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> 8. 
<line: 27> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 28> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count III are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 31> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TITLE]
<line: 33> COUNT IV - BATTERY

[TITLE]
<line: 35> (Andrew Terrell and Silver Lake)

[TEXT]
<line: 37> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 38> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count III, as 
<line: 39> though fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference.

<line: 44> -7- 

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 8 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 14. The conduct and force used by PETER DIANGI toward the Plaintiff, ANDREW 
<line: 5> TERRELL, was intentional, malicious and excessive and in reckless disregard of the Plaintiffs' 
<line: 6> constitutional rights. Moreover, the use of force used against the Plaintiff was excessive. 

[TEXT]
<line: 8> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 9> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 11> 15. 
<line: 12> At all times relevant herein the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was engaged in his 
<line: 13> ordinary duties as a security guard and employee, agent, apparent agent, and/or servant of the 
<line: 14> Defendant, SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 17> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 19> 16. 
<line: 20> At all times set forth in Paragraphs 1-13, PETER DIANGI knew that the 
<line: 21> Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, was legally on the premises of Silver Lake Country Club. 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 24> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> 17. 
<line: 27> The Defendant's conduct in striking the Plaintiff and spraying the Plaintiff with 
<line: 28> mace was unjustified and excessive. 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 31> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 33> 18. 
<line: 34>  As a result of the aforementioned conduct of the Defendants, the Plaintiff 
<line: 35> suffered serious injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including 
<line: 36> physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 38> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 39> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 41> -8- 

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 9 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 19. 
<line: 5> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 6> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 8> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 9> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 11> 20. 
<line: 12> The Defendant, SILVER LAKE, is vicariously liable for the actions and conduct 
<line: 13> of PETER DIANGI. 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count IV are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 16> defendant makes no answer to same 

[TITLE]
<line: 18> COUNT V-ASSAULT

[TITLE]
<line: 20> (Andrew Terrell v. Silver Lake)

[TEXT]

<line: 23> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count IV, as 
<line: 24> though fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference.

<line: 27> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> 14. The conduct of Defendant, SILVER LAKE, by and through its employee and agent, 
<line: 30> PETER DIANGI, placed Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, in apprehension of immediate and 
<line: 31> imminent harm to his well being and safety, and he suffered great shame and humiliation and 
<line: 32> injury to his dignity and feelings, upsetting them mentally, emotionally and psychologically. 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count V are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 35> defendant makes no answer to same.

[TITLE]
<line: 4> COUNT VI – NEGLIGENCE

[TITLE]
<line: 6> (Andrew Terrell v. Silver Lake)

[TEXT]
<line: 8> 1. 
<line: 9> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, was a duly licensed 
<line: 10> corporation, incorporated in the State of Illinois and doing business as Silver Lake Country Club 
<line: 11> and located at 14700 South 82"d Avenue in the City of Orland Park, County of Cook, and State 
<line: 12> of Illinois. 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 15> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> 2. 
<line: 18> Prior to March 18, 2006, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, hired and employed the 
<line: 19> Defendant, PETER DIANGI, as a security guard at the Silver Lake Country Club.  

[TEXT]
<line: 21> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 22> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> 3. 
<line: 25>  On or about March 18, 2006, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was working as a 
<line: 26> security guard and performing his ordinary duties as an employee or agent of the Defendant, 
<line: 27> SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 30> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> 4. 
<line: 33>  On or about March 18, 2006, the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, and his fiancée 
<line: 34> were married at Queen of Martyrs Church in Evergreen Park. Immediately after the wedding 
<line: 35> ceremony, the plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, his fiancée, and various other members of the 

[ABANDON]
<line: 37> -10-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 11 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> wedding guests, including the Plaintiff GEORGE TERRELL, attended a wedding reception at 
<line: 5> Silver Lake Country Club. 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 8> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> 5.
<line: 11> During the course of the reception, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was engaged 
<line: 12> in his ordinary duties as a security guard and was working in his capacity as employee or agent 
<line: 13> of the Defendant, SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 16> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> 6. 
<line: 19> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant SILVER LAKE, through its 
<line: 20> employees and agents, including PETER DIANGI, owed a duty of ordinary care to the Plaintiff 
<line: 21> to hire well-qualified security personnel, and to ensure that the security acted appropriately 
<line: 22> providing security. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 25> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 27> 7. 
<line: 28> On March 18, 2006, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, through its employees 
<line: 29> and/or agents, including the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, breached his aforesaid duties to the 
<line: 30> Plaintiff by engaging in one or more of the following negligent acts or omissions: 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> a. 
<line: 33> Negligently failed to properly train the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, as a 
<line: 34> security guard responsible for providing security to patron during social 
<line: 35> events at SILVER LAKE; 
<line: 36> b. 
<line: 37> Negligently failed to adequately supervise the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, 
<line: 38> during the performance of his duties as a security guard; 
<line: 39> c. 
<line: 40> Negligently permitted the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, to work as a 
<line: 41> security guard without sufficient assistance or supervision; 

[ABANDON]
<line: 43> -11-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 12 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> d. 
<line: 5> Negligently failed to provide adequate security personnel to assist the 
<line: 6> Defendant, PETER DIANGI, in providing security; 
<line: 7> e. 
<line: 8> Negligently hired the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, as a security officer.  

[TEXT]
<line: 10> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 11> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 13> 8. 
<line: 14> In addition to the aforesaid negligent acts and/or omissions, the Defendant, J 
<line: 15> SILVER LAKE, is vicariously liable for the negligent acts and/or omissions, the Defendant, 
<line: 16> PETER DIANGI, as alleged in Count III above. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 19> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> 9. 
<line: 22> As a result of the aforementioned conduct of the Defendants, the Plaintiff 
<line: 23> suffered serious physical injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, 
<line: 24> including physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 27> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> 10. 
<line: 30> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 31> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 33> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count VI are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 34> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TITLE]
<line: 36> COUNT VII-BATTERY

[TITLE]
<line: 38> (Andrew Terrell v. Orland Park)

[TEXT]
<line: 40> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 41> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count V, as though 

[ABANDON]
<line: 43> -12-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 13 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference. 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> ANSWER: Defendant re-adopts and re-alleges its answers to paragraphs 1 through 13, inclusive 
<line: 7> of the common factual allegations section as its answers to paragraph 1 through 13 of Count VII, 
<line: 8> as fully set forth herein and incorporated by referenced. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> 14. 
<line: 11> The conduct and force used by PETER DIANGI as stated herein was intentional, 
<line: 12> malicious, excessive and in reckless disregard of the Plaintiffs' constitutional rights. Moreover, 
<line: 13> the use of force used against the Plaintiff was excessive. 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations set forth in paragraph fourteen.  

[TEXT]
<line: 17> 15. 
<line: 18> As a result of the aforementioned conduct of the Defendants, the Plaintiff 
<line: 19> suffered serious injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including 
<line: 20> physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations set forth in paragraph fifteen.  

[TEXT]
<line: 24> 16. 
<line: 25> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 26> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations set forth in paragraph sixteen.  

[TEXT]
<line: 30> 17. 
<line: 31> The Defendant, ORLAND PARK, is vicariously liable for the actionable conduct 
<line: 32> of its employees, agents, and/or servants including PETER DIANGI. 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations set forth in paragraph seventeen.  

[TEXT]
<line: 36> WHEREFORE, the defendant, Village of Orland Park, denies that it is liable in any 
<line: 37> amount whatsoever, to plaintiff, Andrew Terrell, and demands judgment in its favor on all 
<line: 38> remaining pleadings. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 40> -13-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 14 of 39

[TITLE]
<line: 4> COUNT VIII-ASSAULT

[TITLE]
<line: 6> (Andrew Terrell v. Orland Park)

[TEXT]
<line: 8> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 9> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count VI, as 
<line: 10> though fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference. 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> ANSWER: Defendant re-adopts and re-alleges its answers to paragraphs 1 through 13, inclusive 
<line: 13> of the common factual allegations section as its answers to paragraph 1 through 13 of Count 
<line: 14> VIII, as fully set forth herein and incorporated by referenced. 

[TEXT]
<line: 16>  14.  The conduct of Defendant, ORLAND PARK, by and through its employee and/or 
<line: 17> agent, PETER DIANGI, placed Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, in apprehension of immediate 
<line: 18> and imminent harm to his well being and safety, and he suffered great shame and humiliation 
<line: 19> and injury to his dignity and feelings, upsetting them mentally, emotionally and psychologically. 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations set forth in paragraph fourteen.  

[TITLE]

[TITLE]
<line: 25> (Andrew Terrell v. Peter Diangi)

[TEXT]

<line: 28> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count VII, as

<line: 32> defendant makes no answer to same.

<line: 36> from their willful and wanton acts or omissions while engaged in the execution or enforcement

[TEXT]

<line: 16> unreasonable search and seizure under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to 
<line: 17> the Constitution of the United States (Art. IV, U.S. Constitution, Art. XIV, U.S. 
<line: 18> Constitution.); and 
<line: 19> b.

<line: 21> due process of law, and the right to the equal protection of the laws, secured by 
<line: 22> the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States (Art. XIV, 
<line: 23> U.S. Constitution).

<line: 26> sub-paragraphs (a) through (b), inclusive

<line: 30> its officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, regarding proper procedure to be used 
<line: 31> in apprehending a suspect, including the proper use of force. 

[TEXT]
<line: 33> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph seventeen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 35> 18.

<line: 37> officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, following excessive use of force by 
<line: 38> police such that its officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, were led to believe 
<line: 39> that the consequences of failing to follow proper procedure in the exercise of force were minimal 
<line: 40> or nonexistent.

<line: 10> the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, as a security guard.

<line: 13> defendant makes no answer to same.

<line: 17> corporation, incorporated in the State of Illinois and doing business as Silver Lake Country Club 
<line: 18> and located at 14700 South 82nd Avenue in the City of Orland Park, County of Cook, and State 
<line: 19> of Illinois.

<line: 22> defendant makes no answer to same.

<line: 28> wedding guests, including the Plaintiff GEORGE TERRELL, attended a wedding reception at

[TEXT]

<line: 29> corporation, incorporated in the State of Illinois and doing business as Silver Lake Country Club  
<line: 30> and located at 14700 South 82nd Avenue in the City of Orland Park, County of Cook, and State 
<line: 31> of Illinois.

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 2. 
<line: 5> Prior to March 18, 2006, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, hired and employed the 
<line: 6> Defendant PETER DIANGI, as a security guard at the Silver Lake Country Club.  

[TEXT]
<line: 8> ANSWER: 
<line: 9> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 10> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> 3. 
<line: 13> On or about March 18, 2006, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was working as a 
<line: 14> security guard and performing his ordinary duties as an employee or agent of the Defendant, 
<line: 15> SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> ANSWER: 
<line: 18> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 19> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> 4. 
<line: 22> On  or about March 18, 2006, the Plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, and his fiancée 
<line: 23> were married at Queen of Martyrs Church in Evergreen Park. Immediately after the wedding 
<line: 24> ceremony, the plaintiff, ANDREW TERRELL, his fiancée, and various other members  
<line: 25> of the wedding guests, including the Plaintiff GEORGE TERRELL, attended a wedding 
<line: 26> reception at Silver Lake Country Club. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> ANSWER: 
<line: 29> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 30> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> 5. 
<line: 33> During the course of the reception, the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, was 
<line: 34> engaged in his ordinary duties as a security guard and was working in his capacity as employee 
<line: 35> or agent of the Defendant, SILVER LAKE. 

[TEXT]
<line: 37> ANSWER: 
<line: 38> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 39> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 41> 6. 
<line: 42> At all times relevant herein, the Defendant SILVER LAKE, through its 
<line: 43> employees and agents, including PETER DIANGI, owed a duty of ordinary care to the Plaintiff 

[ABANDON]
<line: 45> -26-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 27 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> to hire well-qualified security personnel, and to ensure that the security acted appropriately when 
<line: 5> providing security. 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> ANSWER: 
<line: 8> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 9> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 11> 7. 
<line: 12> On March 18, 2006, the Defendant, SILVER LAKE, through its employees 
<line: 13> and/or agents, including the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, breached his aforesaid duties to the 
<line: 14> Plaintiff by engaging in one or more of the following negligent acts or omissions: 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> a. 
<line: 17> Negligently failed to properly train the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, as a security 
<line: 18> guard responsible for providing security to patron during social events at SILVER 
<line: 19> LAKE; 
<line: 20> b. 
<line: 21> Negligently failed to adequately supervise the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, 
<line: 22> during the performance of his duties as a security guard; 
<line: 23> c. 
<line: 24> Negligently permitted the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, to work as a security 
<line: 25> guard without sufficient assistance or supervision; 
<line: 26> d. 
<line: 27> Negligently failed to provide adequate security personnel to assist the Defendant,        
<line: 28> PETER DIANGI, in providing security; 
<line: 29> e. 
<line: 30> Negligently hired the Defendant, PETER DIANGI, as a security officer. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> ANSWER: 
<line: 33> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 34> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 36> 8. 
<line: 37> In addition to aforesaid negligent acts and/or omissions, the Defendant SILVER 
<line: 38> LAKE, is vicariously liable for the negligent acts and/or omissions of the Defendant, PETER 
<line: 39> DIANGI, as alleged in Count XIV above. 

[TEXT]
<line: 41> ANSWER: 
<line: 42> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 43> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 45> -27-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 28 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 9.

<line: 6> serious physical injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including 
<line: 7> physical and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> ANSWER: 
<line: 10> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 11> this defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 13> 10. 
<line: 14> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 15> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> ANSWER: 
<line: 18> As the allegations set forth in Count XVII are not directed toward this defendant, 
<line: 19> this defendant makes no answer to same.

[TITLE]
<line: 4> COUNT XX-WILLFUL & WANTON

[TITLE]
<line: 6> (George Terrell v. Peter Diangi)

[TEXT]
<line: 8> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 9> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count XVI, as 
<line: 10> though fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference. 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count XX are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 13> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> 14. 
<line: 16> Pursuant to 745 ILCS 10/2-202, police officers are liable for injuries resulting 
<line: 17> from their willful and wanton acts or omissions while engaged in the execution or enforcement 
<line: 18> of the law. 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count XX are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 21> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> 15. 
<line: 24> At all time set forth in Paragraphs 1-13, PETER DIANGI, knew that the Plaintiff, 
<line: 25> GEORGE TERRELL, was legally upon the premises of Silver Lake Country Club.  

[TEXT]
<line: 27> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count XX are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 28> defendant makes no answer to same. 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> 16. 
<line: 31> At all time set forth in Paragraphs 1-13, PETER DIANGI was engaged in the 
<line: 32> execution or enforcement of the law when he grabbed and/or struck the Plaintiff, GEORGE 
<line: 33> TERRELL. More over, PETER DIANGI engaged in willful and wanton conduct during said 
<line: 34> execution or enforcement of the law by using excessive force in attempting to arrest GEORGE 
<line: 35> TERRELL. 

[TEXT]
<line: 37> ANSWER: As the allegations set forth in Count XX are not directed toward this defendant, this 
<line: 38> defendant makes no answer to same.

<line: 34> from willful and wanton acts or omissions of police officers while engaged in the execution or 
<line: 35> enforcement of the law.

<line: 8> during said execution or enforcement of the law by using excessive force in attempting to arrest 
<line: 9> GEORGE TERRELL.

[TITLE]
<line: 31> COUNT XXII-42 U.S.C. S1983

[TITLE]
<line: 33> (George Terrell)

[TEXT]
<line: 35> 1. through 13. Plaintiff adopts and realleges Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of the COMMON 
<line: 36> FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS section as and for Paragraphs 1-13 inclusive of Count XXII, as 
<line: 37> though fully set forth herein and incorporate the same by reference.

<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 33 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> of the common factual allegations section as its answers to paragraph 1 through 13 of Count 
<line: 5> XXII, as fully set forth herein and incorporated by referenced. 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> 13. 
<line: 8> At all time set forth in Paragraphs 1-13, PETER DIANGI, knew that the Plaintiff, 
<line: 9> GEORGE TERRELL, was legally upon the premises of Silver Lake Country Club.  

[TEXT]
<line: 11> ANSWER: Defendant admits the allegations contained in paragraph thirteen.  

[TEXT]
<line: 13> 14. 
<line: 14> At all times set forth in paragraphs 1-13, PETER DIANGI was engaged in the 
<line: 15> execution or enforcement of the law, and was acting under the color of authority when he 
<line: 16> engaged in the conduct alleged herein, and when he arrested the Plaintiff, GEORGE TERRELL. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> ANSWER:  The allegations set forth in paragraph fourteen are conclusion of law or fact and 
<line: 19> therefore defendant makes no answer to same.  To the extent any factual allegations are set forth 
<line: 20> defendant denies such allegations.  

[TEXT]
<line: 22> 15. 
<line: 23> The conduct engaged in by PETER DIANGI was intentional, malicious, and with 
<line: 24> deliberate indifference to the Plaintiff's rights under the constitution. 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> ANSWER:  Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph fifteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> 16. 
<line: 29> The conduct of the Defendants deprived the Plaintiff of the following rights, 
<line: 30> privileges, and immunities secured to him by the Constitution of the United States. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> a. 
<line: 33> The right of the Plaintiff to be secure in his person and effects against 
<line: 34> unreasonable search and seizure under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to 
<line: 35> the Constitution of the United States (Art. IV, U.S. Constitution, Art. XIV, U.S. 
<line: 36> Constitution.); and 
<line: 37> b. 
<line: 38> The right of the Plaintiff not to be deprived of life, liberty, or property without 
<line: 39> due process of law, and the right to the equal protection of the laws, secured by 
<line: 40> the Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of the United States (Art. XIV, 
<line: 41> U.S. Constitution). 

[TEXT]
<line: 43> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph sixteen including those 
<line: 44> allegations contained in subparagraphs (a) through (b), inclusive. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 46> -33-

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 34 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> 17.  
<line: 5> Prior to March 18, 2006, ORLAND PARK failed to properly train and supervise 
<line: 6> its officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, regarding proper procedure to be used 
<line: 7> in apprehending a suspect, including the proper use of force. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph seventeen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 11> 18. 
<line: 12> In addition, prior to March 18, 2006, ORLAND PARK failed to discipline its 
<line: 13> officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, following excessive use of force by 
<line: 14> police such that its officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, were led to believe 
<line: 15> that the consequences of failing to follow proper procedure in the exercise of force were minimal 
<line: 16> or nonexistent. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph eighteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> 19. 
<line: 21> As a result of the failure of ORLAND PARK to properly train, supervise and 
<line: 22> discipline its officers, including, but not limited to PETER DIANGI, the Plaintiff suffered 
<line: 23> serious injuries. Plaintiff also incurred medical expenses and other damages, including physical 
<line: 24> and emotional pain and suffering. 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph nineteen. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> 20. 
<line: 29> The Plaintiff's injuries were the proximate result of Defendant's aforementioned 
<line: 30> conduct. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> ANSWER: Defendant denies the allegations contained in paragraph twenty. 

[TEXT]

<line: 35> amount whatsoever, to plaintiff, George Terrell, and demands judgment in its favor on all 
<line: 36> remaining pleadings.

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 35 of 39

[TITLE]
<line: 4> AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSES

[TEXT]
<line: 6> NOW COMES the Defendant, VILLAGE OF ORLAND PARK, and for its Affirmative 
<line: 7> Defenses to Plaintiff's Amended Complaint, without prejudice to the above and foregoing 
<line: 8> answers, and in the alternative, states as follows: 

[TITLE]
<line: 10> FIRST AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 12> The Complaint fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted. 

[TITLE]
<line: 14> SECOND AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 16> Plaintiffs' claims are barred in whole or in part to the extent that they have failed to 
<line: 17> mitigate, minimize, or avoid any damages they have allegedly sustained. 

[TITLE]
<line: 19> THIRD AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 21> Whatever injuries and damages Plaintiffs may have sustained at the time and place alleged 
<line: 22> in their Complaint were caused by, and arose out of, Plaintiffs' own intentional misconduct, 
<line: 23> including their failure to abide by the instructions of a sworn peace officer. 

[TITLE]
<line: 25> FOURTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 27> Orland Park police officers had probable cause to arrest Plaintiffs. 

[TITLE]
<line: 29> FIFTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 31> At all times relevant to the allegations of Plaintiffs' Amended Complaint, Defendant Peter 
<line: 32> Diangi and other Orland Park police officers acted in good faith and in accordance with the 
<line: 33> Constitution and laws of the United States and the State of Illinois. 

[TITLE]
<line: 35> SIXTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 37> Defendant Peter Diangi acted toward Plaintiffs without malice and without intent to cause 
<line: 38> a deprivation of constitutional rights or other injury to Plaintiffs. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 40> -35-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 36 of 39

[TITLE]
<line: 4> SEVENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 6> Should it be determined that Diangi was functioning as an Orland Park Police officer on 
<line: 7> the date in question, Defendant Peter Diangi was acting pursuant to the policies and general 
<line: 8> orders of the Village of Orland Park Police Department, in conformance with existing statutory 
<line: 9> and case law, thereby affording him with qualified immunity form liability under 42 U.S.C. § 
<line: 10> 1983.  

[TITLE]
<line: 12> EIGHTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 14> Should it be determined that Diangi was functioning as an Orland Park Police officer on 
<line: 15> the date in question, Defendant Peter DiAngi's use of force in the course of arresting Plaintiffs 
<line: 16> were reasonable, applied in self-defense and/or in the defense of others including bystanders and 
<line: 17> one another. 

[TITLE]
<line: 19> NINTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 21> The plaintiff cannot recover punitive damages against Orland Park. Section 2-102 of the 
<line: 22> Illinois Tort Immunity Act [745 ILCS 10/2-1-2] provides in pertinent part that a local public 
<line: 23> entity such as Orland Park is not liable to pay punitive or exemplary damages in any action 
<line: 24> brought directly or indirectly against it by an injured party or a third party. 

[TITLE]
<line: 26> TENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 28> Should it be determined that Diangi was functioning as an Orland Park Police officer on 
<line: 29> the date in question, Defendant Peter DiAngi's arrest of Plaintiffs on March 18, 2006 was an act 
<line: 30> in the execution or enforcement of a law; Defendant Peter DiAngi's actions in arresting Plaintiff 
<line: 31> were not willful and wanton conduct; Defendant Peter Diangi is therefore immune from any 
<line: 32> common-law liability to Plaintiffs pursuant to Section 2-202 of the Illinois Local Governmental 
<line: 33> and Governmental Employees Tort Immunity Act, 745 ILCS 10/2-202. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 35> -36-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 37 of 39

[TITLE]
<line: 4> ELEVENTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 6> Should it be determined that Diangi was functioning as an Orland Park Police officer on 
<line: 7> the date in question, Defendant Peter DiAngi's arrest of Plaintiffs on March 18, 2006 was an act 
<line: 8> occurring within the scope of his public employment as a police officer, a position involving the 
<line: 9> exercise of discretion and requiring judgment; and Defendant Peter Diangi is therefore immune from 
<line: 10> any common-law liability to Plaintiffs for punitive damages pursuant to Section 2-213 of the 
<line: 11> Illinois Local Governmental and Governmental Employees Tort Immunity Act, 745 ILCS 10/2-
<line: 12> 213. 

[TITLE]
<line: 14> TWELFTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE

[TEXT]
<line: 16> Should it be determined that Diangi was functioning as an Orland Park Police officer on 
<line: 17> the date in question, Defendant Peter Diangi' s arrest of Plaintiffs on March 18, 2006 was an act 
<line: 18> occurring within the scope of his public employment as a police officer, a position involving the 
<line: 19> determination of policy or the exercise of discretion, and Defendant Peter Diangi is therefore 
<line: 20> immune from any common-law liability to Plaintiffs pursuant to Section 2201 of the Illinois Local 
<line: 21> Governmental and Governmental Employees Tort Immunity Act, 745 ILCS 10/2-201. 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> WHEREFORE, the Defendant  VILLAGE OF ORLAND PARK for the complaint to be 
<line: 24> dismissed with prejudice, for the costs of this action, attorneys fees under 42 U.S.C. § 1988 and for 
<line: 25> such other relief as this Court deems just and equitable under the circumstances. 

[TEXT]
<line: 27> DEFENDANT DEMANDS TRIAL BY JURY.  

[ABANDON]
<line: 29> LITCHFIELD CAVO LLP  
<line: 30> By: s/ Jeannine S. Gilleran ___
<line: 31> Attorney for Defendant 
<line: 32> VILLAGE OF ORLAND PARK  

[ABANDON]
<line: 34> Jeannine S. Gilleran, Esq.  
<line: 35> LITCHFIELD CAVO, LLP  
<line: 36> 303 West Madison Street  
<line: 37> Chicago, IL 60606-3300 

[ABANDON]
<line: 39> -37-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 38 of 39

[TEXT]
<line: 4> Jeannine S. Gilleran being first duly sworn on oath deposes and states that he is one of the 
<line: 5> attorneys for defendant,  Peter Diangi and that she has insufficient information to form a belief as to 
<line: 6> the truth or falsity of the allegations contained within paragraphs number 6 of common factual 
<line: 7> allegations and paragraph number 3 of Count XIV of  the Plaintiff's Amended Complaint at Law. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> By: 
<line: 10> /s/ Jeannine S. Gilleran  

[ABANDON]
<line: 12> -38-

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 1:08-cv-02430     Document 30      Filed 07/18/2008     Page 39 of 39

[TITLE]
<line: 4> CERTIFICATE OF SERVICE

[TEXT]
<line: 6> I, the undersigned, being first duly sworn upon oath, depose, and say that I caused to be 
<line: 7> served Defendant Village of Orland Park’s Answer to Plaintiff’s Amended Complaint at Law by 
<line: 8> electronically filing the same with the Clerk for the U.S. District Court for the Northern District 
<line: 9> of Illinois, Eastern Division, a copy of which was then forwarded to each attorney of record on 
<line: 10> the 18th day of July,  2008. 

[TITLE]
<line: 12> /s/ Jeannine S. Gilleran  

[TEXT]
<line: 14> Jeannine S. Gilleran  
<line: 15> LITCHFIELD CAVO LLP.  
<line: 16> 303 West Madison Street  
<line: 17> Suite 300 
<line: 18> Chicago, IL 60606 
<line: 19> (312) 781-6677 
<line: 20> (312) 781-6630 fax  

[ABANDON]
<line: 22> -39-
